author: 17tigalloway

description.text: Teste

A WILD BULBASAUR APPEARED! I created this model using Blender. It is my first model i created using this program. I used the front and side pictures for reference.
This took me, overall 8-10 hours to design.
I am currently doing a test print and see how it turns out and change anything if need be, then do a large scale print of it. I will be working on another file, that has bulbasaur with no seed, drop a radius into his back with small radius holes at the bottom to allow water to flow through, print, spray with clear coat, plant a seed in some dirt and grow your own bulbasaur seed :) If you have any questions or feedback, please don't hesitate to ask me.
if you add my designs to your collection, please don't be afraid to hit the like button too :) NOTE: I have updated the file once again. I have worked more on the eyes, so they aren't so close to the eyelid, and fixed a few vertices here and there. I have also used netfabb to clean and fix any errors or bugs. enjoy :) Pokemon is owned by nintendo/ gamefreak/Creatures Inc

Once you load the STL file using Makerbot Desktop, it will ask if you want to upscale object. Click rescale and then move to bed. I used my 5th Gen Replicator to print Bulbasaur.
Settings i used-
Infill- 7%
shells- 2
Layer height- 0.10mm Estimated time- 6 hours 26 minutes I made this using Blender.
Search the internet, i used google, and search "bulbasaur reference"
Try find a pic with both the side and front together, as they're usually the same size.
If they aren't, then you need to try and scaling the two pics you are using, so they're relatively close to the same height and all proportioned.
You can add more refrence pics, like top view and back view, but for 3D modelling, all you need is the front and side. Once you have you pics aligned and at the same height, add a cube mesh and start pulling and adding vertices. Let me know if you have any questions :)

title: Replicator Bed Level Jig for Makerbot HBP Leveler

description.text: Use this to level your HBP easily with a digital device so you don't have to subjectively go by "feel" with a piece of paper. phineasjw's original leveler had holes that were too small for the magnets to be press fit. Also, the sides next to the magnet were too thin and tended to crack. My version has reinforced sides and bigger holes for easy no drilling press fit assembly. Enjoy! Update 11/24/12; suggested fill changed to 25% from 80%. Lower fill allows the model to deform easier in order to accomodate the magnets. The higher percentage fill version was very difficult to press fit the magnets. I invite you to visit 3dPrintFileMarket.com to enjoy more cool 3d print files. 3d Print File Market is not just another 3d printing website. It is the home of The Original Technology Accelerator App that will change the world.

Print at 25% fill, 0.2mm layer height, bed temp 110C, nozzle temp 227C, 1 shell. All else at default settings.
  • Print
  • press magnets to fit. use a wrench to push it in. install magnets while item is still hot and on the hbp to avoid plastic cracking between layers.
  • press the indicator to fit. twist it in.
    • Bill of Materials;
  • Harbor Freight Magnets SKU 67488: http://www.harborfreight.com/10-piece-rare-earth-magnets-67488.html
  • Harbor Freight Indicator SKU 93295: http://www.harborfreight.com/1-inch-sae-metric-digital-indicator-93295.html
  • Harbor Freight Feeler Gauge SKU 32214: http://www.harborfreight.com/32-piece-sae-metric-feeler-gauge-32214.html
    • Use Instructions:
    http://youtu.be/hgWeew6SmjQ

comments.text: I had the most success printing this on it's back. It prevented the holes from deforming and gave it more sticking area.

description.text: This is my version for a clothing door hook to hang your clothing on. After the one I got at Wal-Mart broke on me, instead of buying a new one, i decided to design one myself :)

The door clothing hook consist of the three .STL parts for construction and some other parts that you can find at a Home Depot or any home hardware store. Parts list:
  • Print 2 copies of door hook.STL
  • Print 1 copy of center door hook.STL
  • Print as many clothing hook 2.STL as you wish
  • .25 diameter metal rod at least 18" long or as long as you want it to be.
    • Construction is simple, after printing each part, a drill maybe needed to size the holes to allow the metal rod to pass through if the holes didn't print accurately. First, fit the first door hook on one end of the metal rod.
    Second, add as many clothing hooks as you wish.
    Third, fit the center hook at the midpoint of the metal rod length that you have chosen for support.
    Forth, add as many clothing hooks as you wish.
    Last, add the other door hook on the oppose it. Finally place the hole assembly on your door and start hanging your clothes or whatever you wish. fyi: My door thickness is about 1.38", the hook is 1.41" so if your doors are within that range there shouldn't be any problem hooking it up. Also in the pictures I had designed a light module that is attached to the center door hook. I didn't include it yet because I want to redesign it so stay tuned for an update.

description.text:
Sony Xperia Z Ultra, what better phone to bring on a trip?  
It's nearly perfect for watching movies on the plane, train, hotel, where ever.  
One of the things making it so perfect is that it's compact enough to bring everywhere.  
With that in mind I have created this simple stand that wont take any place in your pocket and still give the phone a stable, comfortable angle.  
I've tried it on my last plane trip without hassle.  
It's also good looking so it works just as well on your desk at work.  
It prints in under one hour and uses only 11,54 cm3 of material.  
It does not support the Xperia Z Ultra phone standing up, due to it's size, this is for movies mainly.  
Ofc it works with other phones, check the specs of the Xperia Z Ultra thickness to see if it fits yours.  
This project was made possible by www.protech.se
Orient it on its side for best surface.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

SCH40 PVC 3/4" Pipe Clamp
Mounting hardware: #6 self tapping screw
Clamping hardware: #8 machine screw Application: Mount PVC pipe to wooden platform to make a horizontal hot wire foam cutting assembly. CAD development chain:
OpenSCAD used to modify original OpenSCAD file. Modified file was exported to .csg format. .csg file was imported into FreeCAD. FreeCAD was used to produce .stl for part production with ReplicatorG. Circuitous CAD development chain was used to verify OpenSCAD to FreeCAD to ReplicatorG functionality. OpenSCAD is capable of exporting .stl files directly for production.
ID of clamp was set +1mm over OD of PVC tube to account for dimensional variance of Thing-O-Matic print process. Other production machines may not require +1mm margin.

comments.text:
I have checked the position of polygons and the document contains no errors. Generally, in these situations, the problem often comes from feedrate speed parrametres and diameter of the filament. First, check that your filament has a diameter of 1.75... if this is not the case, change the diameter in the parameter of your Slicer to match the diameter of you filament. Also decrease of about 20% to 40% your feedrate speed parrameters...
Normally it will fix the problem... Keep me posted.

author: jlavoie

description.text:
The "AT-AS" (All Terrain - Anita Scout) is a printable quadruped robot. The AT-AS is a project of an efficient robot, as it has achieved a useful and complete walking robot base using few technical and economic resources. In addition, it is a flexible robot project since its design is open to many development possibilities in future works such as the transformation of the quadruped model to a hexapod model, easy modification of leg and modular structure design, the possibility of adding sensors to improve control or communication with other robots using wireless networks via Xbee modules. I used two parts of the "Versatile Servo Bracket System" created by bryanandaimee:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5784
But the rest of parts has been designed by my own, using OpenSCAD and C++ OOML (Oriented-Object Mechanical Library): http://iearobotics.com/oomlwiki/doku.php?id=start For the AT-AS implementation, I used:
  • 1x Arduino Mega 2560.
  • 8x Servo Futaba S3003.
  • 1x Lipo Battery (2S, 7,4V).
  • 1x UBEC (5V).
  • Remote control through a Gamepad connected to a PC.
  • Wireless communication through Bluetooth or XBee modules.
    • But this robot accepts others microcontrollers, servos (with similar dimensions) and others components for its control. Use the one you prefer! See a video of AT-AS quadruped in action:
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ae2UiOCUZeY&feature=g-upl
The part called: "hip_evolution_hexapod" is only for the transformation of the quadruped model to a hexapod model. Using this part, just need to print another two legs! :)
(A further update with the programming & instructions of installation will be available soon.)

Create a finger skate using VITTEL bottle caps.

• Dessiner et couper au laser les differentes pièces qui
    composeront le moule. Bien huiler les différentes pièces

  • Faire fondre les bouchons en polyethylène sur une plaque
    chauffante. Bien aérer et porter un masque.

  • Utiliser une spatule en bois pour étaler la pâte dans le moule.
    Cette étape doit être rapide.

  • Immediatement serrer le couvercle du moule à l’aide de serre-joins.

  • Après quelques minutes, le couvercle peut être ouvert, et le moule démonté. la pièce devrait pouvoir être retiré facilement.

  • Assembler les roues sur les trucks. Disposer les trucks sur les
    bossage sous la planche. Avec un briquet, faire ramollir les deux
    bossage et verrouiller les trucks.

title: Marblevator "Mini", Seesaw Edition.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This version of the Marblevator Mini series features a seesaw and basin. The seesaw directs alternating marbles to alternating ends of the basin. Video of prototype here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RuKmjNzfECM. Note the sign is not included, it was simply used to accentuate the seesaw motion. Designed for use with multiple marbles. Designed to use the base assembly of the Marblevator Mini here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:286045. Simply push out the worm gear and Bowl Track, then snap on the Seesaw track and replace the worm gear. And finally, if you don't mind manual labor, the hand cranked version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:310488. Designed using Sketchup 8 and printed in PLA on a Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42. "Track.stl" and "Basin.stl" were printed "High" resolution, the remaining parts printed in "Standard" resolution.

See the instructions for the Marblevator Mini here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:286045. If you already built the Marblevator Mini, you can use that base for the Seesaw Edition. "Assembly.skp" contains additional assembly notes. Depending on your printer settings, you may need to file and sand the areas indicated for smooth operation.

description.text: Ever had someone question your ability to differentiate between Dothraki and Klingon? Ever have someone assume you need help configuring your wifi settings? Ever had a kid try to explain to you the concept of a sonic screwdriver? Well I have, and there is nothing worse than having your Nerd credentials questioned. That is why I invented Nerd Card. Nothing says, I'm a Nerd, like pulling out a 3D printed Nerd Card. Nerd Card is the size of a credit card and slides easily into a purse or wallet. It doesn't matter what type of Nerd you are, there is a Nerd Card for you. Go for the Original Nerd Card, 8-bit Nerd Card or the Sci-Fi Nerd Card. The only way you can go wrong is by not carrying one. The 3 Nerd Card designs comes in a plastic saving Cut Out version perfect for stenciling a bulkhead, blaster or computer case. The Nerd Card also comes in an engraved version designed for 2 color prints. Print a Nerd Card in your Pyramid or Quidditch team colors. Be proud of who you are. Show the world that you are a Nerd! I'm publishing the Nerd Card designs to celebrate the first anniversary of my blog, designmaketeach.com, and Twitter account, @DesignMakeTeach. I'm also giving away a physical copy of the Nerd Card to a lucky reader http://designmaketeach.com/2014/04/15/happy-1-year-reader-give-away/
The Nerd Card is 0.8mm in height. Recommend printing at a 0.2mm layer height. Swap filament after 0.4mm (end of layer 2) for a 2 color print.

comments.text:
The suspension or revocation of a Nerd Card is a serious matter that should not be undertaken lightly. Community standards for Nerd sub-groups vary greatly. What is acceptable at an Engineering School Halloween Party is not the same as what is acceptable for a 501st Legion event. Regardless, any Nerd should have recourse to a Nerd Trial if publicly challenged about the right to bear a Nerd Card. Typical challenges can be resolved by a few rounds of rock-paper-scissors-lizard-Spock, D20 roll, trivia battle, or a Nerd Off. Judgement by a full Tri-Nerd council should be reserved for only the most serious cases at large Nerd gatherings. Be warned that the challenger is subject to suspension of their Nerd Card for a 24 hour period if unfairly challenging the right of a fellow Nerd to bear the Nerd Card.
As the inventor of the Nerd Card, I challenge my fellow Nerds to spread the Nerd cause by passing on Nerd Cards to the worthy few.

description.text: This cap is designed to be tapped into place over the end of a piece of rebar to make it more visible, and more difficult to hurt one's self on. This is embossed with the burning man logo, available in the OpenSCAD Burning Man Logo library found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30094 The design is only parametric in that you can adjust for the size of rebar you're using. Changing other variables may break the design.
This is best printed in a high-visibility color, perhaps a bright blue to contrast with the playa.  Print, then lightly tap into place on the end of your rebar with a hammer.

These are all the files for the RepRap Darwin v1.0.6! I'm putting them here in the hopes of getting more folks obsessed with the RepRap project!
Here is the description from the RepRap site:
Look at your computer setup and imagine that you hooked up a 3D printer. Instead of printing on bits of paper this 3D printer makes real, robust, mechanical parts. To give you an idea of how robust, think Lego bricks and you're in the right area. You could make lots of useful stuff, but interestingly you could also make most of the parts to make another 3D printer. That would be a machine that could copy itself.
RepRap is short for Replicating Rapid-prototyper. It is the practical self-copying 3D printer shown on the right - a self-replicating machine. This 3D printer builds the parts up in layers of plastic. This technology already exists, but the cheapest commercial machine would cost you about â‚¬30,000. And it isn't even designed so that it can make itself. So what the RepRap team are doing is to develop and to give away the designs for a much cheaper machine with the novel capability of being able to self-copy (material costs are about â‚¬500). That way it's accessible to small communities in the developing world as well as individuals in the developed world. Following the principles of the Free Software Movement we are distributing the RepRap machine at no cost to everyone under the GNU General Public Licence. So, if you have a RepRap machine, you can use it to make another and give that one to a friend...
The RepRap project became widely known after a large press coverage in March 2005, though the idea goes back to a paper on the web written by Adrian Bowyer on 2 February 2004.
RepRap Version 1.0 "Darwin" can be built by anyone now - see the Make your own RepRap link there or on the left, and for ways to get the bits and pieces you need, see the Obtaining Parts link.

title: Smartrap X End Mount For J-Head Light and MK5

description.text: This is a X end mount for the Ohio Plastics J-head Light hotend. The hotend is longer than most and using default J-Head mount for the Smartrap results in ~20mm loss of build height. This mount should restore the build height and removes the servo for auto-leveling. NOTE: This design has now been made and tested. I have found that for the Smartrap, the Left mount and arm are working better than the right due to the way the Bowden tube is run. Screws are M3-20 and there is a thin plastic washer between the arm and mount. I plan on using a piece of plastic cut from a plastic milk jug or pop bottle. There is a provision to use a grub screw to adjust trip of the micro switch, adjustable through the bottom of the arm rest through a clearance hole, or can be used without. Edit (1) - The CAD files are in FreeCAD format. FreeCAD is an open source, free to use, parametric solid modeler CAx program. To view and edit the files, download the latest version of FreeCAD from http://www.freecadweb.org Edit (2) - Updated New_jhead_X.stl and New_jhead_X.fcstd files to include slot for tystrap (belt drive) and tie holes for Spectra line (string drive). Also updated the New_jHead_X_Assembly.fcstd file to include the new revision. Edit (3) - Added New_MK5jhead_X_Mount_ArmPushConnect.stl, New_MK5jhead_X_Mount_Arm.stl, and New_MK5jhead_X_Mount_Retainer.stl along with corresponding FreeCAD files. These are 2 versions of the arm for the MK5 J-head Hotend. One for the use of a push connect and the other for using a nut on the Bowden tube. The retainer fits both parts. Edit (4) Revised X End mount and Arm and included a left and right hand version. Added mounting for 30 mm fan to Retainer as an option. Edit (5) Made a quick video showing the J-Head Mount in action on my Smartrap - http://youtu.be/JXZshkgj2z4 Edit (6) Small update to the Left and Right Arm mount for the J-Head Light. Improved the forks that hold the nut and Bowden tube. Made them a bit longer and wider. Should help with less than perfice prints. Edit (7) Added MK5 J-Head retainer with 30 mm fan mount. Note - Fan mounts diagonal.

comments.text:
The Z limit switch is hooked up just like the X and Y are. They are plugged into the pins designated for the limit switches on the RAMPS board. The Smartrap has only one limit switch per axis and the other end is software defined.
Here is an image of the board and the hook ups for the limit switches - https://raw.githubusercontent.com/smartfriendz/smartrap/master/doc/smartrap%20ramps%20connections.jpghttps://raw.githubusercontent....
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Thanks!  I see where you have marked the servo end.  If I were to put in a Z Max end stop, can both this and the the Z Max switches be connected to the same pin?
comments.author: quick61

comments.text: No, the Z min is the endstop switch and the Z max pins are repurposed for activation of the servo. But with this design here, the servo is no longer needed and the tip of the extruder probes the bed directly, and activates the Z limit switch

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

This is a SD Card Holder with internal springs that hold the cards in place.  
Apparently SD Cards have quite some tolerances in their size. When I printed a block with simple slits, some of my cards were totally loose and others I could only get in the holder with force. Therefore i design a holder that keeps the cards in place with small springs.   
I recommend printing it with ABS since it is more elastic at room temperature. However, I also printed it in PLA and is works as well.  
I like actually the fact, that the only way fabricating this object is using a  3D printer. It's not possible to mill it or use injection molding.

comments.text:
Actually, when it's worth the extra effort and cost they do injection mold complex, severe undercuts with fusible cores. A low melting point alloy is first molded into the core shape and the plastic is injected around it. Induction heating is the common way to melt them out.
The springs are a great idea. They need to bend so little compared to their length I doubt they will ever take a "set".... ABS in particular has a point of no return, so to speak. Gonna print a couple tonight. Thanks.

title: Two Pronged Shower hook
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Couldn't find a shower hook that did what I wanted it too so made my own. Used the locking connectors from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10701
Created by davidlvann I just built around a scaled down version of the connectors in Google SketchUp and netfabb Studio. I got the bobble on the end of the hoop idea from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11070
Created by smartroad The hoop has a diameter of 25mm ish. Why I used the connector, I cant remember but you could just print the hoop make sure it fits then print the hooks or you could adapt the hooks and add more hooks or maybe less hooks. Parametric Locking Connectors (davidlvann) / CC BY-SA 3.0 S Hook (smartroad) / CC BY-NC 3.0

Scale the hoop to the diameter you need, also scale the hooks or they wont lock together. Print. What I like to do is pull the hoop off the heatbed and run to the bathroom!
Attach it on the shower rail, pinch it round the tube then cool with water, if you have any handy.

A tool tray and bottom support bracket for all of your Felix 3D printing tools and accessories! If you LIKE this, click on the HEART! :)

There are two parts to this accessory; the tool tray and the lower bracket. Simply scuff up the bottom of the tray with some sandpaper and glue the bracket, centered to the bottom with the slot clip protruding at the same side as the hole, with super glue. Then snap the tray bracket into any convenient location on the frame to support weight of the tools in the tray. Secure the tool tray by putting a single M4X10 (4mmX10MM) bolt through the exiting hole and secure it to a shiny metal t-slot brace. Both items should be spares in your Felix DIY kit. Voila! If you want to put smaller items in any of the compartments just cut some heavy photo paper to size. I did just that to the smaller compartment to hold my hex wrenches.

description.text: A spool roller/idler which is easily ("OTED") adjusted to spool widths from about 50mm to 125mm. In the blender file attached, just modify the frame for a different range to your liking or needs. I never found a spool idler fitting my 2.3 kg spools from ReprapWorld, and I was never certain that I would get those spools again. So, I mocked up this design where the 608-guides in one side are confined while the 608-guides on the other side may slide freely on the axles in a wide range. The frame is not too nice, and warps easily for me. I will probably make a new design which should print faster, warp less (rounded corners), and use less material. However, for now this one works very fine. (Note: OTED, One Touch Exchange of Die, came out of development towards just-in-time production control at Toyota by a really smart guy, Shigeo Shingo. If interested in flexible manufacturing go for his book "A Study of the Toyota Production System", ISBN 0-915299-17-8. Or just get some interesting information at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OTED)

Print or get two 150mm long 8mm smooth rods.
Print one frame.
Print four "608 belt guides".
Print eight spacers. Aditionally you need four standard 608 bearings, and, if you did not print them, two 150mm long 8mm smooth rods. N.B.: The "608 belt guides" should have a very snug fit to the bearing. Hence, you may have to adjust the size in the .blend- file or scale the stl to fit your mis-calibration. Assembly is straight forward. The smooth rods should have stickout enough to mount a standard clamp, but it is not necessary.

title: Super Stubby Swivel Screw Driver / Hand Drill

description.text:
So I wanted a super screwdriver!  Had to be small yet balanced, universal, yet fit in the palm of my hand, and able to be used with one hand.  
No lasers?  Na not this time ;)
I present my swivel driver.
Used blender to add superness.
Added a small paw version with less weight and more plastic.   Still very balanced.

You will need Americans
1- 1/2 in 5/16 bolt
3- 5/16 washers
5/16 Tap
608z Bearing Everyone that uses the Metric System that are smarter than Americans. Yes I am an opressed metric American.
35mm- M8 Bolt
3 M8 washers
m8 Tap
608Z bearing For the hand drill you will need the 1/4 chuck adapter found in most hardware stores. Metric people ... hmm have no clue if you have such a thing. Instructions... Tap the handle! Place the bearing and 3 washers on bolt.
Screw bolt into handle
Place handle nub over bearing Enjoy!

title: Bridge spacer for Fender Stratocaster tremolo bridge

description.text: This is an easy way to block off the tremolo bridge on a Fender Stratocaster, if you aren't using the tremolo bar. I made this to fit a 2006-ish Mexican Strat, but it may fit other models.
Print this with at least 20% infill. You really should put this in when there are no strings on the guitar, as it will prevent strain on the neck and the strings.

Easter is coming, so you're going to need a way to display your best Easter eggs. Ditch the traditional egg cups and turn your Easter into an Ogo Eggstravangaza!

You can print at a low resolution with a raft and supports. I would suggest printing these on their sides so the joints are stronger.

This is a modification of an iPhone 4 case that I found on Thingiverse, which I modified to make it wrap around the iPhone 4 better (made it 1mm taller). And I cut out my initials because it kinda looks cool. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/bcDNf8u1Tqu . In particular, if you make a copy and tinker it, you can ungroup it and make your own personalized cutout. I'm not sure which iPhone case this is derived from. If you recognize let me know and I'll credit it appropriately.

Print, snap your phone into place.
Fits perfectly when printed in PLA.

comments.text: would have been cool without your intials.

comments.text: Yeah, but he did link to TinkerCAD, so it's super easy to edit the initials out, or replace them with your own. Even if you've never used any kind of imaging software in your life, you can use TinkerCAD.

comments.text: I guess I needed to be more specific. The model is in TinkerCAD, so that anyone can put their own initials in the case, or whatever else they want. If you go to the link you can make a copy and tinker with that.

comments.text: Oh, one thing to keep in mind - if you put your own initials in, the initials have to read properly from below the bottom of the case, so the letters have to be "backwards" if you are looking at the front of the case. Obvious in retrospect, but didn't catch it until printing one (looked fine on screen, where I was looking at the front of the case)...

The parts required to mount your PSU underneath the bed on a MM 1.5+. Note that most older Y axis configurations do not leave enough space for the PSU to mount under the table. You can see pictures of how to install the parts at http://www.flickr.com/photos/dawgdayz/sets/72157631797286081/with/8099483674/
You will need feet like http://www.mcmaster.com/#9540K32 or a similar printed foot to allow sufficient clearance for the power supply.

comments.text: Looks like PS1 and PS2 need to be flipped before printing.Â  As they are in the STL files, they will be printed upside-down with impossible overhangs.
comments.author: naught47

comments.text:
I positioned PS1 & 2 that way so the top surface will be facing out. The bit of sagging you will get is not mechanically critical, so it was a sacrifice I was willing to make for the aesthetics of the finished part, but feel free to flip them if you prefer.Â 
I'm not quite sure how you are installing parts 3 & 4, but they do all line up if it is installed correctly. You can see how to install them in the photo set at http://www.flickr.com/photos/dawgdayz/sets/72157631797286081/with/8099483674/http://www.flickr.com/photos/d...Â
comments.author: naught47

comments.text: Â I added a picture to the "Made One" section showing the alignment problem I'm seeing.

comments.text: I looked closer at the parts on my bot here and I think you are right that there is a slight difference in the heights, however they do work fine. The middle might sit a couple MM lower, but it does not cause any issues.

description.text:
I dont really like the charger cables for apple stuff, they bend and break too easy. (no strain relief) its almost as if they are designed to break.
I made this for an ipad cable, I think iphone etc are the same.

Just print (must be ABS for flexibility, PLA will break) insert the cable in the obvious way. it will take up most of flex, but it could probably be improved with a bit more tweaking.
I used 1 wall and 15% fill, you might be able to do 2 wall and 0 percent fill for more consistant bending, need to test a bit more

This is a model of the lamp housing that usually melts in many 70's era Marantz receivers. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:150349 for a more printable remix.

I haven't yet printed this, very soon....
It should be a direct replacement part for part #0917 in the 2250 service manual (available for download from audiokarma.org).  If yours is melted like mine, you'll know exactly what part you're replacing.
Expect some updates as I print/adjust it to fit.
It could probably be cut on a CNC mill as well, but that's not a tool I have experience with.

I recently picked up an old vinyl cutter on the cheap. I wanted to be able to use it to draw with a sharpie, unfortunately, the top of the cutter prevented this. As such, I made a mount to angle the pen out.
I think my cutter is an earlier model of the refine vinyl cutters (it uses the same driver and looks similar) so it should work with them and other similar models as well.

Use a M3 bolt and nut to lock the pen in place, push the leg into the tool holder on the cutter, tighten it up and you're good to go. I've had a bit of fun with stipplegen http://www.evilmadscientist.com/2012/stipplegen-weighted-voronoi-stippling-and-tsp-paths-in-processing/
I've used it to make both TSPs and stipple images, definitely worth having a play if you haven't already.

Here is a helping hand jig that is useful for soldering, gluing, painting and macro photography. It is highly configurable to hold various small objects in many positions. The helping hand has six configurable, lock in place, arms with interchangeable grippers. It was printed on a Replicator 2. The gripper donuts can be cast in silicone or Oogoo and were cast using donutmold.stl. More details on the build can be found at: http://www.instructables.com/id/Make-An-Ultimate-Helping-Hand-Jig/

description.text:
Years ago in college I took a sculpture/3D Construction type Art class. One of the projects was to make a kind of Unit - a 3D shape out of like paper, or cardboard or such. But, make MANY of them. Then, take all those pieces and create a sculpture with it. Too bad I lost that sculpture over the years. So - I've been wanting to do something like this via 3D Printing. Then, recently when browsing on Thingiverse here - I came across the Customizer App that allowed you to create geometric shapes. As such, it was the PERFECT Starting point. I created the TetraHedra. But, I then took it - and split the sides of each leg. Then - on 2 sides I pushed it outwards - and 2 sides are pushed Inwards. Thus - 2 Tetras will fit together! I also decided to make the initial ones BIG - so once I 3D Print a BUNCH of them - I could assemble together and make a REALLY Big Sculpture! My buddy "JetGuy" said - to build a Temporary structure - to plan a sculpture - use Hot Glue gun to put pieces together. Then, you can take them back apart by applying Isopropyl alcohol to the glued joints. That will make them come back apart. If you want to make them smaller - just reduce size by a percentage and do that for all pieces you print. I also made a smaller stretched piece I call a "foot" - and 3 of them on the bottom of the bottom piece of sculpture will lift it up! But, they are small - and thin - and may or may not hold things up. Will have to experiment more... Addendum: This Thing has been online for a couple years now. It was originally based upon a Customizer here on TVerse. I attempted to find that original Customizer - I found this one - not sure if its THE One - but, it WILL work: http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=233540 In addition, I now added 2 new pics here. In 2017 I finally managed to print ton of the Blocks, between 40-50 of them. So, at my day job I built a simple sculpture - sitting on a white table top, which is the one pic. Started out as an Aluminum Mendel and morphed into a bit of this and a bit of that. Mostly a learning exercise. An engineer printed the extruder for me in his commercial 3d printer. Made the Budaschnozzle with some modifications. I had a box of semi-circular half inch Thomson rod bearings given to me that necessitated using half inch rod. The bearings are very sensitive to clamping pressure and I would not use them again if I were starting anew. I used 80/20 stuff for most of the structure since I had a lot of scrap to choose from. No idea if any of this will work yet. I have Ramps 1.4 electronics to hook up to experiment with. That will be another learning exercise since this is my first build!

To use the semi-circular bearings I made double sets of the plywood frames and bolted them together with laser cut spacers. Then I slip fit the bearings already on rods into the double frames and used silicone sealant to fix them in place.

Openscad library for easily attaching parts. This is an experimental work on enhancing the openscad tool. Usually the code written by users is difficult to read and understand. If we want to share the code and to reuse parts made by others, it is very important to write clean code. The attach operator is a experimental way of joining together parts. It just hides all the translate/rotate operators to the user, making the code easier to read, maitain and reuse. I have written about it (and given an example of use) in this post: http://www.iearobotics.com/blog/2012/09/10/enhancing-openscad-with-the-attach-library/ The attach operator is part of the obiscad tools I am developing: https://github.com/Obijuan/obiscad More information in this wiki (in Spanish): http://www.iearobotics.com/wiki/index.php?title=Obiscad

Reprap to CNC Router

Construction:
Print CNC_ROUTER_CLIP001.STL and CNC_ROUTER_BED001.STL.
Power tool is using BLACK & DECKER High Performance Rotary Tool and RTX Flex Shaft.
Fix CNC_ROUTER_BED001 on the original extruder by M3 screw and nut.
Clip CNC_ROUTER_CLIP001 on the flex shaft with bit of the power tool by M3 screw and nut.
Fix the drilling head on the CNC_ROUTER_CLIP001 by screw and nut. Software:
Skeinforge. Change Profile Type : Milling. Profile Selection : End Mill.
Import STL file to Skeinforge to generate G-CODE.
RepSnapper. Import G-CODE. Drilling speed:
..... over 10,000 to 30,000 depends on materials. Caution:
Remember to wear a dust mask, safety glasses, earmuffs.

Mailbox made from plywood, manufactured using the laser cutter.

We didn't have a proper mailbox, so we designed one of our own using only plywood and the laser cutting machine. 
The plywood has a thickness of 4mm. It consists of 2 main parts, the box and the cover, and one alternative third part, so we could attach it to a tube. On the sides there are recesses which makes parts fit together. They are attached to each other using glue. 
The box and the cover are fixed to each other using a bolt of 4mm. 
We also engraved our house number and name on the front and on the cover with the laser cutter. 
The part to attach it to the tube is seperate from the back of the mailbox so that it is possible to remove it. We secured it tot the tube using tieraps.
There are 3 DXF files containging al the parts you need to make the mailbox.

Large calibration matrix (145mm x 145mm) to identify backlash and other hard to resolve print quality issues.

Print and play.  Will give you a good idea of how your print quality varies over the x and y limits of the bed, and also of the first 20mm of the Z axis as well.
This was very helpful for me in identifying defects in printed pulleys or shafts - eg errors that are introduced at very specific intervals or only in specific ares of the print bed.
Obviously, you must start with a level print surface, the vertical and horizontal lines are 1mm.

title: Bracket For RAMPS On Kossel Mini

description.text:
This bracket is designed to mount an Arduino Mega + RAMPS sandwich to 15mm OpenBeam in what would seem like the least convenient position - sticking straight out from the beam. The idea being to solidly mount the print controller to the bottom-most beam under the print bed of a Kossel Mini. This significantly reduces the bulk of the wiring in the uprights (lots of heavy wires + a few thin -> a few heavy wires + lots of thin), and hides the rats-nest under the print bed.
It's not particularly convenient for tweaking motor drive current, and you'll want to hook up an external reset button (if you don't already have a controller) but it looks much tidier. 2014-4-25: Figured out why the .skp was so huge - cleaned out the components list (there was some ridiculous stuff in there) and re-uploaded. No changes to the part, just housekeeping.

title: Printed Motor Mount for Sherline Machines

description.text:
Put together as I'm refitting a manual Sherline mill for CNC use.  Note the measurements for screw mounts seem OK but may be off by a few thou.  
Requires 2 x SFR4 flanged bearings each (plus motor couplers and mounting screws, of course).  
Tested so far for fit (with bearings), but will be a bit yet before I'm able to test function.

Seems pretty strong with 0.7 infill, 0.2 layer height ABS though not a bad idea to print solid.  Reasonably good bridging is necessary.  
Clean up membrane over the mount & bearing holes.  Bearings go in either side of the back wall.  
I've not yet found a preferred motor coupler & sorted out preloading.

title: Wade's Geared Nema 17 Extruder for Bfb Hotend

description.text:
This is a modification of Wades extruder to fit a hot-end from BfB.
I made holes to mount the hot-end, and removed all not-needed holes.
I also moved the mounting holes so the filament holes is exactly in the middle of it. All other parts are unmodified, and should be taken from the original. You will also need a modified carriage if you want to use this on mendel.
You can find that under http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3017 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3016 You can find more info on this on:
http://ifeelbeta.de/index.php/production/wades-extruder-with-bfb-hot-end
Print the Extruder body, mount the Bfb hot-end, assemble everything else, have fun.

title: dji phantom 2 any lead acid rc charger adaptor

description.text:
just set you lipo charger to lead acid charge like 3 or 4 amps 12v out
and you can charge your phantom 2 5200 3s smart battery i used a old transformer 110 AC plug for leads just bend or cut and solder to wires the pos and neg is labeled I'm my pic of battery being plugged in also red pos and darker color neg i just plugged into battery and then super light super glue to hold them straight then un plugged and added super glue filler i think backing soda should work as a filer to hold wires in place permanent you might use 5min epoxy as well but make shire that you don't glue it to the battery . i used qbond black powder as a filler

comments.text: Dangerous.  Leading to people setting fires
comments.author: newt2015

comments.text: 69maverick and derrick84, I have been flying RC heli's and plains along with ground pounders for many many years (over 20 years now before Li-Po's were the thing) and I happen to have two Hitec X4 AC Plus chargers which will charge pretty much 4 of any battery at once SO. I thought this was interesting cuz the stock charger that came with my Phantom Pro puts out 17.5V at 5.7A so I hooked my oscilloscope up and tested the wave form and sure enough it is regular DC current. Now with that said 69maverick is right about having to balance any Li-Po battery (they only need balanced about every 10-20 cycles depends on how hard you are on them. get yourself a Blinkie if you have regular Li-Po's they are great if your charger doesn't balance while charging) BUT the DJI batteries I have for said quad above has a built in balancer and converter which is how its able to discharge it's self after so many days of sitting at full charge.
comments.author: Volcom7114

comments.text: Charging LIPO batteries like that will burn your house down. This is not a good idea. Not to mention you are not balancing them So they won't last long.
comments.author: 69maverick

comments.text: yes if you charge a regular lipo with out balancing,  then you will reduce your battery life and its not as safe, Not the case with a phantom 2 battery it is internally charge regulated and balanced.  this means this way of charging is the same as the stock phantom charger in all regards, it is same as oem charger so its great because now you can use any 12v constant power supply to charge as many phantom 2 batters at same time

author: UltiBots

description.text:
This is still a work in progress but I have printed and assembled. I created a automatic fish feeder that will use a arduino board that will rotate the auger every 12 hours to feed my fish. I will also have a manual override switch to feed the fish at any time. My old fish feeder was made out of cardboard so I thought it was time to 3D print one.
Update:
4/20/2014
Added Arduino program for fish feeder. Also new Youtube video on how the feeder works.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OZY4djtZuTU
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YOIEwJ1nbWU 8/20/2014
Added my source files for editing. You can download them at this link. https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B0mS2ccz6lQNQnowYnpEQmZTWkk&usp=sharing 11/26/2014
Add Arduino Nano board case to fit the board, transistor, wires and button to look cleaner than having all the wires and board exposed. Added file and picture to project. I just hot glued the board to the hopper case. Working on a way to fasten without hot glue for next update.

Printed out in ABS. The servo motor I used was from HobbyKing. http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=16269 It was a 38 gram servo motor.
For the lid I used a piece of PLA filament and rolled it out straight on the heated bed on my printer and used that as my pin for the hinge. I melted the ends so it is locked in.
Took out the circuit board in the servo and soldered wires directly to motor to make the servo a dc motor. Included arduino program to run feeder. Used 5 volt from arduino board and a 3906 transistor to switch on the motor also need a LED and tactile switch for manual feed. Program feeds fish every 12 hrs on a timer.

title: Table mount for portable music stand

description.text: I designed a portable magic table with props space, MP3 sound, and a close-up surface.  The stand is a very portable music stand, and I needed a way to mount the table to the stand quickly; hence the table mount.

Hi,
This is a rear wheel design for Scalextric; for a W8101 tyre set. I accidently bought the tyres for this wheel on ebay (had different wheels); so I decided to make this wheel to fit the tyres. Note: I thought the best way to get a good print was to split the wheel (as shown) into 2 STL files, and print the wheel in 2 parts. Then glue them together. I did not want to print this in one go, with supports etc.... Any thoughts on this ??

Print both parts of the wheel separately. Insert the shaft into both parts of the wheel (to center it), then glue both parts & retain with a clamp.  
Use best resolution, and high in-fill setting

description.text: This is my latest 3-dimensional model of a partial chain of cellulose. I obtained the pdb file of cellulose from London South Bank University's website. The model was constructed from this protein data bank file, was manipulated in the program VMD, and was then further manipulated in tinkercad. I replaced all of the bonds once I imported it into tinkercad. For some reason, they don't come across properly, but the spheres look just fine. I fixed these by manually replacing these with cylinders in tinkercad (took a couple of hours). The current print turned out very nice, but I made some additions to further support it here. I also broke out the model paints and painted the final version. Pictures are included. I constructed it so that multiple chains could be strung together, but do not yet know how well it will work. I'll print out a couple of more and try to post more later.

I am printing this with a raft (no supports needed, as I have manually provided my own). My first print was at medium quality. The raft makes it easier to separate the mounts from the replicator base. Once completed, the mounts need to be removed. You can find links on wikipedia if you want to paint the atoms the correct color, as I have done. I might do something similar with DNA.

title: razor blade scraper with cover and retention tabs

description.text:
Razor blade scraper for getting under prints. Adds locking tabs to the original model, as part of the holder body and on a slide-in clip that engages the outside notches on a double ended razor blade to retain the blade so that it doesn't come loose when you pull back to recover. Includes slip cover for safety when not in use. UPDATE: I have a redrawn version with a better blade retention mechanism here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:697672
Give it a try if you want to make sure the blade never slips out.

Print holder, cover, and retainer; other STL files are to show assembly. Print holder at 0.15mm layer height and 0.40mm extrusion width if possible. The retention clip is small and may ooze from insufficient cooling. If it seems too big to fit in the slot, you may need to take a file to it. As in the source model, there is a single track of filament on the side of the holder where you slide in the blade to provide a bridging point for the blade slot which you will need to break. A sharp knife and some twisting works well.  
Slide the razor in from the side and push it all the way across, making sure it engages the retention tab in the body. Then insert the clip with the outer portion on top of the holder. The slip cover should fit with the clip in place.

comments.text: The upgrade seems to solve the bending problem as well as it keeps the blade in place. I only had to cut a part of the tab so that the cover gets in place fully (see my make). Nice job!

This is based off a mid-60's (we're guessing) egg separator that works very well.  However it's now glued together with epoxy :)  At first I tried to "clone it" - but decided to make the bowl section more "egg shaped" and seems to seperate the egg better!
I wanted to make a replacement and came across Tinkercad (first 3d design ever)!  After 7 versions and a lot of plastic as I was trying to calibrate my Replicator at the same time, I came up with this.
You may wonder why the walls are so thick... you can easily remove the chalaza without touching the yoke - be very careful when removing this.
"Egg Separator" is embossed on the back.

Printed with 30% infill, 1 shell in Print-o-matic (2 shells total), full support no raft. Since support material by default in Skeinforge goes left to right along the x-axis (unless you've changed it), rotate the egg separator 90 degrees counter clockwise/clockwise. NOTE: The plastic/brass nozzles etc.. of 3D printers are not food safe please take this into consideration when printing this. Everyone probably already knows this. Lego is made from ABS and young children chew on them. I personally do not see it being an issue. If anyone is concerned about voids in their prints where water/egg could enter and grow mold, I would avoid printing this. 100% infill or an extra shell might make it safer against voids, however I have not done this and I do not know how it would turn out. 1) Print using the plastic of your choice (PLA is probably a better choice)
2) Carefully remove the support
3) File the mouth/spout area with a small file
4) Wet sand both inside and outside of the mouth/spout area (I used 400 & 600 grit)
5) Crack egg and slowly pour off the white
6) Optionally you use your finger to remove the Chalaza (removed for a more uniform texture in baking) NOTE: If your printing this you probably already know this... But the older the egg the more fragile the yoke is, the yoke should be almost round if it "sags" it's old and can break easily when trying to separate it. If any sharp edges remain after printing smooth them out to avoid any egg damage. Pictures with the egg in the separator are from v5 before I made the walls thicker. Original Tinkercad object:
https://tinkercad.com/things/jUdwIispZpa-egg-separator-v7

comments.text: cute design.  There are two food safety caveats to keep in mind with 3d printed things.  First is that the plastics are not food grade.  Most people don't mind/care about this, but its just something to be aware of.  Second is to make sure that your perimeters are solid and that no cracks form that would allow egg or water to enter the hollow inside (or print it with 100% infill, but you'll still want to make sure no cracks form).  As this is a food contact thing, it'll go through washings and if water enters the hollow insides, there'll be no way to get it and the eventual mold/bacteria out.  Just be cautious to check it after each washing and/or before each use.

This is the low-cost prototype of a robotic arm with 6 DOF, 3D printers manufactured and designed using free software (OpenScad, Inksape..).

You only have to print all parts and mount it with the instructions. Download the assembly instructions file and start it to mount. if you want see how work , click here!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JnvWSHTnrqo&feature=plcp
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BNnTyrpuFUY&feature=plcp The file "robot arm printable.rar" contains all the files of OpenScad and .stl, ready to print. The other file "robotic arm_freeCAD.rar" contains the robotic arm already mounted in FreeCAD All the information that you need to control the robotic arm is in the file "Guide,PCB_and_control_programs.rar". It's contains the guide about all the caracteristics of the robotic arm and the process that you have to follow to calibrate it with the control's programs. All the information is in spanish, there isn't an english version. The hardware that use is Arduino UNO, to read the position of the servos, you need make a PCB ( if only want move it, you don't need create the PCB) because have the signals multiplexed. The planes are in the same file of the control's programs. To open the planes, you need have OrCAD Layout to the PCB and OrCAD Capture CIS for the schematic of conection. Another partner (http://www.thingiverse.com/CarlosRZambrana) was created a simulator to control the robotic arm , with three modes of funcionality, one mode of control is with a gamepad. I still haven't got the programs but I will upload this in the future when he pass me all the files to upload it. You can see the simulator in the pictures. If you want the simulator's files, you can wait my upload or send a message to CarlosRZambrana to get it, or ask him all doubt that you have about the simulator). you can download the gripper from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7109

comments.text: hola ancastrog  queria saber como solucionaste el tema de las velocidades ? o solo se frena en el video por el hecho de que esta haciendo mucha fuerza ?o estas usando otro soft ?  desde ya muchas gracias
comments.author: agus

comments.text: Hola agus, no se muy bien a que te refieres con lo de las velocidades... utilizo los programas que aparecen en la documentación para controlarlo por el puerto serie del PC. En el vídeo el brazo se frena porque utilizo servos "trucados" para controlarlo en posición con realimentación, de manera que se la envío y al llegar a la posición se para. El control en velocidad no está implementado... está planteado como posible mejora, pero aún sin desarrollar. Puedes observar que algunos GDL van más lentos que otros, esto no es un control en velocidad, simplemente se les ralentizó porque durante las pruebas debido a la inercia que cogía el brazo al ir de una posición a otra bastante alejada, partía los dientes de los engranajes del servo por frenar bruscamente y se decidió "reducir la velocidad" en esos servos por software, pero no es un control en velocidad. Un saludo.
comments.author: agus

comments.text: aaaaa claro !! eso es lo que yo veo en la reaccion de los servos ! van muy rapido y mi medio es romperlos ! como hiciste para hacer la realimentacion que me nombras ! te molesto por el hecho de que es parte de una linea de embotellamiento y no quiero pasar un mal momento en la presentacion... !! desde ya muchas gracias

comments.text:
Hola, gracias! no he logrado conseguir el simulador para controlarlo, la única forma de que puedas conseguirlo es poniéndote en contacto directamente con mi compañero que lo hizo (el enlace a su perfil esta en la descripción de arriba), si aún así no logras contactar con él, puedes programar con Arduino un programa que sea capaz de controlarlo, bien desde cero, o bien utilizando el programa que diseñé y que está colgado, de manera que tu programa solo envíe los comandos necesarios en cada momento a mi programa según lo necesite y que se encuentran explicados en el .pdf adjunto en los archivos de descarga.
Puedes programarlo de tal manera que muevas el brazo con potenciómetros. El único inconveniente de tener los dos programas (el tuyo y el mío, es que requieres de dos microcontroladores, uno para cada programa. Un saludo.
comments.author: agus

comments.text: Hola ancastrog segun entiendo el programa que pones se llama FreedCAD con ese puedo abrir los archivos, yo el unico que uso es AutoCAD, el FreedCAD es en 3d verdad? Entonces no podria ver las medidas o si? Muchas Gracias de ante mano por el post tan bueno 10+!!
comments.author: Schleswig

comments.text: Hola, en autoCAD no sé si permite abrir los archivos y si se podría sacar las medidas... Las piezas están creadas con OpenSCAD. FreCAD se ha utilizado para realizar el ensamblaje de todas las piezas y crear el modelo tridimensional montado. FreCAD es un programa libre que permite crear diseños en tres dimensiones, tengo entendido que hay una herramienta (icono con forma de regla) que permite sacar un valor aproximado de las dimensiones, tomando longitudes entre dos puntos que selecciones, pero no se como es exactamente... Una posible forma, sería en OpenSCAD abrir el archivo y dibujar rectángulos tridimensionales de una determinada longitud, trasladándolos y rotándolos a lo largo de los tres ejes para sacar aproximadamente las medidas que te interesen con él... es un proceso bastante pesado, pero no he encontrado aún otra manera de obtener las medidas de manera sencilla a partir de las piezas  creadas...
comments.author: Schleswig

This is your scan from Monday 14th April 2014 at Making It ... at the Museum. We hope you had a great time at our new exhibition.
If you had fun remember that there are loads more excellent events at Edinburgh International Science Festival every day until 20th April. Just view yourself in the 'Thingiviewer' to see how cool you look in all 3 dimensions, or download yourself as an .stl file.
To look at your 3D self on your computer you will need to download an .stl viewer - there are lots of open-source .stl viewers available online for free. Search for 'free stl viewer' to find one for yourself.
